prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Angular Resolution: We require the best angular resolution in CO J=1-0 in order to resolve the spiral arms and the nuclei, assuming the nuclei are separated more than 250 pc and not along the same line of sight. The best resolution is 0.37‚Äù, roughly 30% better than the resolution requested for Project 306 in Cycle 1 observing IRAS 13120-5453.
Correlator Setup: We will use band 3 to observe 12CO J=1-0 in IRAS 13120-5453. We require the widest bandwidth mode (1.875 GHz) with the finest spectral resolution for each of the 4 spectral windows. To decrease the data rate, we will use a spectral averaging factor of 2, which will slightly decrease the spectral resolution to ~3km/s. Since ULIRGs are known to have broad lines (> 200 km/s; Iono et al. 2009), the widest bandwidth mode will ensure that we observe the entire line profile. We place one spectral window to be centered on CN N=1-0 and the other two free spectral windows will be used to measure the continuum. We still use the finest spectral resolution for the continuum spectral windows in case there are unexpected spectral lines in the windows.
Sensitivity: We use Arp 220 observations of CO J=3-2 (Sakamoto et al. 2008) to determine the sensitivity required to detect IRAS 13120-5453. The peak intensity of CO J=3-2 in Arp 220 is 1 Jy/beam at 0.5". IRAS 13120-5453 is more compact than Arp 220 and further away; therefore, we assume it is a point-source within the beam. Arp 220 is roughly 1.70 times closer than IRAS 13120-5453; therefore, we estimate the CO J=3-2 peak in IRAS 13120-5453 to be 350 mJy. We use a line ratio in Jy units (K units) of 3-2/1-0 = 3 (0.35) as observed for Arp 220 (Downes & Solomon 1998). We estimate the peak intensity of CO J=1-0 to be 115 mJy. We also assume that the spiral arms are 40 times less bright than the peak intensity; therefore, we require a sensitivity of 0.5 mJy to have a ~6 sigma detection at a spectral resolution of 30 km/s. The required sensitivity is twice that of the project observing IRAS 13120-5453 in Cycle 1.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 12CO(2-1)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We are observing the ULIRG IRAS 13120-5453 in CO J=1-0 at the best possible resolution.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Angular Resolution: We require the same angular resolution as the proposed CO J=1-0 observations in order to probe the molecular gas on similar spatial scales.
Correlator Setup: We will use band 6 to observe 12CO J=2-1 in IRAS 13120-5453. We require the widest bandwidth mode (1.875 GHz) with the finest spectral resolution for each of the 4 spectral windows. To decrease the data rate, we will use a spectral averaging factor of 2, which will slightly decrease the spectral resolution to ~1.5 km/s. Since ULIRGs are known to have broad lines (> 200 km/s; Iono et al. 2009), the widest bandwidth mode will ensure that we observe the entire line profile. We place the other three spectral windows to measure the continuum and CS J=5-4.
Sensitivity: We use the same method as with the proposed CO (1-0) observations to determine the required sensitivity. We use a line ratio in Jy units (K units) of 3-2/2-1 = 2.5 (1.1; Sakamoto et al. 2008). We estimate the peak flux of CO J=2-1 to be 140 mJy. Assuming the spiral arms are 40 times less bright than the peak, we require a sensitivity of 0.7 mJy for a 5 sigma detection at 20 km/s channel width.
Special Constraints: If we use a channel width of 30 km/s as with the CO J=1-0 observations, the overhead time is greater than 30%; therefore, we decrease the channel width to 20 km/s which increases the total time of the observation.

Angular Resolution: We require the same angular resolution as the proposed CO J=1-0 observations in order to probe the molecular gas on similar spatial scales.
Correlator Setup: We will use band 7 to observe 12CO J=3-2 in IRAS 13120-5453. We require the widest bandwidth mode (1.875 GHz) with the finest spectral resolution for each of the 4 spectral windows. To decrease the data rate, we will use a spectral averaging factor of 2, which will slightly decrease the spectral resolution to ~1 km/s. Since ULIRGs are known to have broad lines (> 200 km/s; Iono et al. 2009), the widest bandwidth mode will ensure that we observe the entire line profile. We require the finest resolution in order to get a good measurement of the line. We place one spectral window to be centered on HCO+ J=4-3 and the last two spectral windows will be used to measure the continuum. We still use a fine spectral resolution for the spectral windows that will be used to measure the continuum in case there are unexpected spectral lines present.
Sensitivity: We use CO J=3-2 observations of Arp 220 (Sakamoto et al. 2008) to estimate the required sensitivity. The peak of the CO J=3-2 line is estimated to be 350 mJy. Assuming that the spiral arms are 40 times less bright as the peak flux, we require a sensitivity of 1.7 mJy for a 5 sigma detection at 8 km/s channel width.
Special Constraints: If we use a channel width of 30 km/s as with the CO J=1-0 observations, the overhead time is greater than 30%; therefore, we decrease the channel width to 8 km/s which increases the total time of the observation.

Angular Resolution: We require the same angular resolution as the proposed CO J=1-0 observations in order to probe the molecular gas on similar spatial scales.
Correlator Setup: We will use band 9 to observe 12CO J=6-5 in IRAS 13120-5453. We require the widest bandwidth mode (1.875 GHz) with the finest spectral resolution for each of the 4 spectral windows. To decrease the data rate, we will use a spectral averaging factor of 2, which will slightly decrease the spectral resolution to ~0.5 km/s. Since ULIRGs are known to have broad lines (> 200 km/s; Iono et al. 2009), the widest bandwidth mode will ensure that we observe the entire line profile. We place two spectral windows around HCO+ and HCN J=7-6; however, due to the weakness of the lines we do not expect detections. The last spectral window will be used to measure the continuum but we still use a fine spectral resolution in case there are unexpected spectral lines present.
Sensitivity: We use the CO J=6-5 peak intensity of Arp 220 (Matsushita et al. 2009) to estimate the required sensitivity to detect CO J=6-5 in IRAS 13120-5453. The peak intensity of Arp 220 in CO J=6-5 is ~400 mJy; therefore, taking distance into account, we estimate the peak intensity of CO J=6-5 in IRAS 13120-5453 to be 140 mJy. Since observations in CO J=6-5 are difficult, we aim to detect the peak intensity at a 35sigma level; therefore, we require a sensitivity of 4 mJy at a 30 km/s channel width.

Angular Resolution: We require the same angular resolution as the proposed CO J=1-0 observations in order to probe the molecular gas on similar spatial scales; however, the best angular resolution of 13CO J=1-0 is slightly larger than 12CO J=1-0.
Correlator Setup: We will use band 3 to observe 13CO J=1-0 in IRAS 13120-5453. We require the widest bandwidth mode (1.875 GHz) with the finest spectral resolution for each of the 4 spectral windows. To decrease the data rate, we will use a spectral averaging factor of 2, which will slightly decrease the spectral resolution to ~3.2 km/s. Since ULIRGs are known to have broad lines (> 200 km/s; Iono et al. 2009), the widest bandwidth mode will ensure that we observe the entire line profile. One spectral window is centered on the CS J=2-1 line. The remaining two spectral windows will be used to measure the continuum but we still use a fine spectral resolution in case there are any unexpected spectral lines present.
Sensitivity: We use a line ratio in Jy units (K units) of 12CO/13CO J=1-0 = 20.5 (19; Aalto et al. 1995) to estimate the required sensitivity. We estimate the peak flux to be 5.7 mJy. We aim to detect IRAS 13120-5453 in 13CO J=1-0 at a 15 sigma with a 30 km/s channel width; therefore, we need a sensitivity of 0.38 mJy.

Angular Resolution: We require the same angular resolution as the proposed CO J=1-0 observations in order to probe the molecular gas on similar spatial scales.
Correlator Setup: We will use band 6 to observe 13CO J=2-1 in IRAS 13120-5453. We require the widest bandwidth mode (1.875 GHz) with the finest spectral resolution for each of the 4 spectral windows. To decrease the data rate, we will use a spectral averaging factor of 2, which will slightly decrease the spectral resolution. Since ULIRGs are known to have broad lines (> 200 km/s; Iono et al. 2009), the widest bandwidth mode will ensure that we observe the entire line profile. The remaining three spectral windows will be used to measure the continuum but we still use a fine spectral resolution in case there are any unexpected spectral lines present.
Sensitivity: We use the line ratio that is observed for Arp 220 in Jy units (K units) of 12CO/13CO J=2-1 = 15.5 (14; Matsushita et al. 2009) to estimate the required sensitivity. We estimate the peak flux to be 9 mJy. We aim to detect IRAS 13120-5453 in 13CO J=2-1 at a 15 sigma with a 25 km/s channel width; therefore, we need a sensitivity of 0.6 mJy.
Special Constraints: If we use a channel width of 30 km/s as with the CO J=1-0 observations, the overhead time is greater than 30%; therefore, we decrease the channel width to 25 km/s which increases the total time of the observation.

Angular Resolution: We require the best possible angular resolution for HCN and HCO+ in order to better match the proposed CO observations.
Correlator Setup: We will use band 3 to observe HCN and HCO+ J=1-0 simultaneously in IRAS 13120-5453. We require the widest bandwidth mode (1.875 GHz) with the finest spectral resolution for each of the 4 spectral windows. To decrease the data rate, we will use a spectral averaging factor of 2, which will slightly decrease the spectral resolution to ~1.6 km/s. Since ULIRGs are known to have broad lines (> 200 km/s; Iono et al. 2009), the widest bandwidth mode will ensure that we observe the entire line profile. The remaining two spectral windows will be used to measure the continuum but we still use a fine spectral resolution in case there are any unexpected spectral lines present.
Sensitivity: We use HCO+ and HCN observations of Arp 220 (Gracia-Carpio et al. 2008) to determine the sensitivity required to detect HCN and HCO+ J=1-0 in IRAS 13120-5453. HCN is seen to be brighter than HCO+ in Arp 220; therefore, we aim to detect HCO+ in IRAS 13120-5453. We use the line ratio in Jy units (K units) of 12CO/HCO+ J=1-0 = 8 (14; Gracia-Carpio et al. 2008) to estimate the required sensitivity. We estimate the peak flux to be 12.5mJy. We require a sensitivity of 0.8 mJy to detect IRAS 13120-5453 in HCO+ at a 15 sigma level with a channel width of 25 km/s
Special Constraints: If we use a channel width of 30 km/s as with the CO J=1-0 observations, the overhead time is greater than 30%; therefore, we decrease the channel width to 25 km/s which increases the total time of the observation.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: IRAS 13120-5453 is the second nearest (D = 137 Mpc) and the least studied Ultra Luminous Infrared Galaxy (ULIRG) with no published ground-based CO observations. We propose to use ALMA to observe IRAS 13120-5453 in several 12CO and 13CO lines. When compared to Arp 220, IRAS 13120-5453 has a similar far-infrared luminosity but optical images show that IRAS 13120-5453 is more compact with ordered structure in the form of spiral arms. We will use the proposed observations to study the distribution and physical conditions of the molecular gas and compare it to other local ULIRGs such as Arp 220 and Mrk 231.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Physics & Astronomy, McMaster University

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Physics & Astronomy, McMaster University
